awd_titl_txt: A Multi-Sightline Investigation of the Complex Circumgalactic Medium
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomers seek to understand how stars and galaxies formed.  Galaxies exist in relation to the diffuse gas that surrounds them.  Understanding this relationship is essential for understanding how galaxies, including our own galaxy (the Milky Way), came into being.  To probe diffuse gas, astronomers use fortuitously aligned, bright background sources that illuminate it.  Chen and collaborators take this method one step further.  They use background sources that have been gravitationally lensed to yield multiple images.  These images probe the gas from multiple lines of sight simultaneously.  This project will produce the first survey of such galaxies and gas together.  Investigators will discover the properties of this gas, including its spatial distribution.  They will understand the inter-relationship between the surrounding gas and galaxies within.  The PI will interact with underrepresented minority high school students through the Space Explorers Program.  The PI will also engage undergraduates in summer research and support one PhD thesis.  The PI will collaborate with Adler Planetarium to develop museum displays that communicate key findings of galaxy evolution.  These activities inspire young people and the general public to participate in science.

This proposed investigation utilizes multiply-lensed quasars (QSOs) and projected QSO pairs to resolve the motion and chemical enrichment of the CircumGalactic Medium (CGM).  The galaxies span a range of morphologies and star formation histories.  Specific scientific objectives include characterizing the diffuse gas halos, particularly its velocity distribution, its dependence upon galaxy properties, and its mechanism of formation.   This project will produce the first large survey of dozens (~60) of spatially and spectrally resolved halo maps at projected distance d < 100 kpc around both star-forming and passive galaxies in the range 0.4 < z < 1.  This project extends prior studies by going to higher redshift and increasing sample size by an order of magnitude.  It will contribute a deeper understanding of the relationship between diffuse CGM halo gas and star formation in galaxies.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored galactic ecosystems by introducing a novel observational technique to study the normally unseen tenuous gas that surrounds stars and galaxies. Although diffuse, this gas plays a vital role in the life cycles of galaxies. Understanding the relationship between gas and galaxies is essential for understanding how galaxies, including our own Milky Way galaxy, came into being. Astronomers typically use fortuitously aligned, bright, background sources which illuminate the diffuse surrounding gas to probe it. The PI took this method to the next level. She used background sources that have been gravitationally lensed to yield multiple images. Instead of one view per background source, these images probe the gas from multiple lines of sight simultaneously, providing spatially-resolved maps for characterizing the density and velocity fields of the clumpy medium.  This effort led to surprising discoveries of kinematically complex neutral gas in the inner halos of massive elliptical galaxies in the distant universe, highlight the need of continuing heating sources to prevent the gas from forming new generations of stars.  In addition, the project utilized 3D spectral imaging data to map this diffuse gas in emission.  This produced the first high-definition maps of extended tenuous gas around distant galaxies and quasars (powered by supermassive black holes), which enabled the PI and a PhD student on the project to derive the first empirical constraints on the scale-dependent turbulent velocity spectrum and the turbulence heating rate in the circumgalactic gas.  These measurements provide a critical first step toward a physical understanding of how feedback energy from stars and supermassive black holes in galaxies are coupled to tenuous halo gas on large scales.

The project supported the development, execution, and publication of a graduate student's PhD thesis.  In addition, the project provided research opportunities for nine undergraduate students through summer research opportunities, including two students from the Leadership Alliance which serves students from groups historically under represented in astronomy. Both the PI and the PhD student have been actively involved in public outreach events to bring this research to broader audiences, including lectures to senior citizens in the Chicago area through the Life Long Learning program, and contributing to the writing of "Astronomy as a Field: A Guide for Aspiring Astrophysicists", crafted to inspire Native girls in middle and high schools to pursue studies in STEM.
